Jason,

> However, I believe that (in most cases) the public interface of 
> any part of
> a system should be designed in such a way that when it is tested the
> programmer can be assured that he/she hasn't broken anything.  The
> package-scope clients usually have a public interface of their 
> own which can
> then be tested separately from the classes they interact with.  

This is fair enough in a "write tests first" situation; I agree
that the tests of the public methods should be exhaustive enough
that they exercise any protected or private methods that are 
utilised by the public methods.

However, the situation I described, and a situation for which I
think JUnit is an excellent tool, is one in which someone is 
refactoring an existing code-base.  I've inherited 15,000+ lines
of code, and want the freedom of being able to "smell a code smell"
and get right in there and fix it up, irrespective of whether the
"smell" occurs in a public, private, or protected method.  However,
before I change ANYTHING in a system that is in production, and
it to all intents and purpose, working, I have to ensure that I
don't break existing functionality.

If my methodology is to "smell the bad smell, write a Unit Test to
confirm how I believe the protected/private method is working, 
refactor the offending code, and then IIABDTTPMIFI" (if it ain't
broke, don't tell the project manager I fixed it) is guaranteed
by rerunning of the JUnit test.

In this instance, I very much see the need to be able to use JUnit
to test protected and private methods.

FWIW, I found the JUnitX package at www.extreme-de.com, which
serves my needs perfectly, and also plugs in to my favourite
architecture level IDE, Together UML.

Glad my occasional thread has prompted so much useful (for me)
discussion !

Best wishes,

Steven
